repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Technical Education and
            Vocational Training Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Specific lessons indicate
            that the experience of demand-driven training programs was
            successful, since requests for training originated from
            micro-enterprises, and responsive, skills upgrading programs
            provided an improved productivity among those enterprises.
            Regrettably, the Bank's operational procedures
            precluded the full disbursement of funds over the six-year
            period, to the training support fund, an issue which needs
            to be reviewed, and simplified. Moreover, although some
            training financing sources exist, diversification of
            financing methods, and alternatives for private financing
            are still needed. It is further suggested that selection of
            construction firms should follow a rigorous process, to
            avoid unnecessary delays, as proven by the difficulties
            encountered in this project, due to the firm's
            difficulties with liquidity in foreign currency. General
            lessons reinforce that institutional, and policy reforms
            follow a political process, and it is this
            process-time-frame which should be precisely estimated, to
            avoid falling behind schedule, due to possible delayed
            adoption of policy statutes. Additionally, performance
            indicators should be specified, in measurable terms, before
            implementation; similarly, impact assessment of training
            programs should be built into the implementation plan.

18154444.theme: Education for the knowledge economy,Participation and civic engagement,Improving labor markets
18154444.majtheme: Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Technical Education and
            Vocational Training Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Mauritania is in the
            process of restructuring its education and training system
            to correct distortions in cost and resource allocation and
            to improve quality and relevance. The ongoing Education
            Sector Restructuring Project, jointly financed by the
            International Development Association (IDA) and the African
            Development Bank (AfDB) supports this initiative and is
            successfully implementing restructuring measures in primary,
            secondary and technical education. However, attempts to
            correct deficiencies in vocational training and make
            training programs more flexible and responsive to labor
            market demands were largely unsuccessful. In technical
            education, following the outflow of skilled foreign workers
            in the early 1990s and a planned sharp reduction of French
            technical assistance serving as instructors, qualitative and
            staffing problems require urgent attention. The principal
            objectives of the project are to help establish a coherent
            system of technical education and vocational training
            (TEVT), staffed largely by national instructors, efficient
            and of good quality, and responsive to labor market demands.
            To this end,  the project supports a number of institutional
            measures to: (a) establish a common management structure for
            the TEVT system; (b) increase the financial and operational
            autonomy of TEVT institutions; and (c) promote the
            participation of employers in operating and financing
            technical and vocational training.
